alternatives.transcript: I just think a little miracle is going to happen that's how I have to function because I'm the one that has to go in front of the camera Sharon Gless bought to save Cagney and Lacey now she battles to save the trials of Rosie O'Neill Entertainment Tonight has the story for this Wednesday November 20th 1991

hi everybody Welcome to Entertainment Tonight I'm John Tesh and I'm Mary Hart 30 years ago was one of the world's high-profile glamour jobs light up a cigarette hold up the pack be a tv spokesman for a tobacco company men who answered that calling or now sorry they ever took a puff and they speak out in today's Inside Story

this one time Marlboro man has cancer this former Winston model suffered a stroke and cancer robbed this one time Lucky Strike girl of her voice box they all blame their health problems on their addiction to the products they once happily promoted let's have a cigarette over the years hundreds of people have appeared in cigarette ads and until the government banned them in 1971 smoking ads filled the airwaves and sometimes featured famous faces Danny Thomas James Garner

Forsythe Dick Van Dyke and Mary Tyler Moore all Hawk cigarettes but for filter and taste Camp satisfies past all except that one time pitchman an ex-smoker Earl Holliman says in those days people were naive about smoking I think actors have a responsibility to be careful what they push but in 1959 we didn't know we didn't know that cigarettes were killing us and today that is just what Wayne McLaren says his 25-year pack and a half a day cigarette habit is now doing to him I don't think I would

do a cigarette advertisement today but in the 70s Wayne McLaren was a Marlboro man projecting the Macho and robust image that help to sell millions of cigarettes now this 51 year old man has cancer and doctors have given him just six months to two years to live today he is speaking out against the products he wants promoted if I was even indirectly responsible

to make someone start to smoke maybe now I can make a couple quick McLaren is not alone other cigarette models who smoked are publicly preaching the dangers of smoking like Janet SackMan a top model in the 50s she did ads for many products including cigarettes she started smoking at age 17 and quit just six years ago the day her doctor told her she had throat cancer and her voice box would have to be removed last year her cancer record today SackMan tries not to think

about the impact or ads may have had if I think about those things too much I can go out of my mind but I just think of what the future all and when I could do the future not all cigarette models smoke and all those who do not all are sick like Eric Claussen he is healthy he smokes and modeled for eight different brands Lawson feels today cigarette ads are honest sand if asked he says he would still appear in one but he does not Advocate smoking they

didn't have warning in big letters you know this may cause cancer and all the stuff on the Billboards and stuff like that today I would have to really think about it but it's all there so there and if you're young you're stupid to smoke and that's the message 41 year old former Winston model David gorlitz is bringing to students at school assemblies by ad where I was a role model to make sure you kids were confused about tobacco was just that it was a scam it was a lie it was a trick it was a deception and I was wrong Winston Representatives told Entertainment Tonight that they're at

ad campaign is not aimed at kids but those over 35 when David gorlice represented Winston he once earned a hundred thousand dollars in a year but almost 80 years ago he suffered a stroke V says as a result of smoking three and a half packs a day for 24 years he has quit smoking and now denounces his former work I would dig ditches before I ever advertise a product that hurt so many people ever again the proportion of Americans who smoke has dropped steeply now down to one out of every four people but sales of American cigarettes are on the rise of Broad and
